This is an Atom formatted XML site feed. It is intended to be viewed in a Newsreader. Alternatively you can view the HTML archives at https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk/cgi-bin/webadmin?A0=HISTORY-GIS.
LISTSERV Web Interface 2.4.1 2015-02-05T11:16:31Z "Alexander Von L\ufffd\ufffdnen" 2015-02-05T12:16:26+01:00 2015-02-05T12:16:26+01:00 Call for Papers https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=HISTORY-GIS;2b20d97d.1502 Full message available at: <a href="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=HISTORY-GIS;2b20d97d.1502">Call for Papers </a> Fischer, Lisa 2015-02-03T23:54:36+00:00 2015-02-03T23:54:36+00:00 CFP: DigitalHeritage 2015 https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=HISTORY-GIS;df4e5f56.1502 Call for Papers for DigitalHeritage 2015<br>The Second International Congress on Digital Heritage<br>September 28 \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd October 2, 2015<br>Granada, Spain<br><br>DigitalHeritage is the biggest international event for scholars working on information technology & cultural heritage. As a federated world congress of the leading international societies & organizations, DigitalHeritage 2015 will bring together VSMM, Eurographics GCH, Arqueolo\ufffd\ufffdgica 2.0, Archaeovirtual, and special events from CAA, CIPA, Space2Place, ICOMOS ICIP, and more, all in one venue with a prestigious joint publication. [...] Don Lafreniere 2015-01-21T08:57:30-05:00 2015-01-21T08:57:30-05:00 CFP: SSHA Baltimore 2015- Historical Geography Network (February 14 deadline) https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=HISTORY-GIS;3144980d.1501 The Historical Geography Network of the Social Science History Association<br>invites you to take part in the 40th annual meeting of the SSHA, November<br>12-15, 2015 in Baltimore, Maryland.<br><br>We are seeking complete panels as well as individual papers.<br><br>The Historical Geography Network has an active membership of scholars who<br>utilize geographic information systems (GIS) and other spatial tools to<br>tackle a wide range of historical problems. We encourage papers and panels<br>that utilize spatial methods to ask new historical questions as well as to<br>revisit old ones. Examples include but are not limited to: [...] Benjamin Vis 2014-12-09T13:59:30+00:00 2014-12-09T13:59:30+00:00 PhD opportunity: \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdAbstract Mapping for Ancient and Contemporaneous Cities\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=HISTORY-GIS;8c4f9873.1412 PhD opportunity on ‘Abstract Mapping for Ancient and Contemporaneous Cities’<br>(Apologies for cross-posting)<br><br>The School of Computing at the University of Kent is currently advertising an exciting and innovative interdisciplinary research project lead by Dr Peter Rodgers<http://www.cs.kent.ac.uk/people/staff/pjr/> (Computing) and Dr Benjamin Vis<http://www.kent.ac.uk/secl/classics/staff/vis.html> (Classical and Archaeological Studies). We are looking for an enthusiastic PhD student with advanced software development skills. The ideal candidate would also have experience with spatial data and a general interest in the archaeological and urban studies expert uses of the diagrammatic visualisations this project will develop.<br>Further information on this project can be found in the list [...] Benjamin Vis 2014-11-30T18:33:58+00:00 2014-11-30T18:33:58+00:00 Funded PhD places available in Digital Humanities at U of Kent https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=HISTORY-GIS;cd1372af.1411 With apologies for cross-posting,<br>The University of Kent is recruiting for new funded PhD places, to join in the 2015/16 academic year. We have a special interest in proposals for Digital Humanities, Digital Heritage, Spatial Humanities, and cross-disciplinary humanities research.<br>Eastern ARC scholarships: http://www.kent.ac.uk/scholarships/postgraduate/eastern_arc.html<br>Eastern ARC is the new research consortium, uniting research capacity in the Digital Humanities and heritage at the universities of Kent, Essex, and UEA. At Kent we are particularly interested in proposals on past built environments, ancient cities, and comparative urbanism, among a few other key areas.<br>CHASE scholarships: Owens 2014-05-29T10:22:17-06:00 2014-05-29T10:22:17-06:00 Beginners' GIS training manual for historians & historical social scientists https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=HISTORY-GIS;118e5975.1405 Dear colleagues,<br><br>Our introductory GIS training manual for historians & historical social<br>scientists is now available for free download at:<br><br>http://www.geographicallyintegratedhistory.com/<br><br>Please note that the data for all of the exercises and the companion GIS<br>software for the first ten chapters are also available for free download.<br><br>Although subscribers to this list will have no personal use for a training<br>manual like this one, I am posting the information here because you may<br>have students or colleagues who would benefit from such a book. Thank you<br>for disseminating information about it. The course will be delivered through presentations [...] Gregory, Ian 2014-05-28T16:43:21+00:00 2014-05-28T16:43:21+00:00 Research Associate/Senior Research Associate in History, Lancaster University https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=HISTORY-GIS;e6a10185.1405 Research Associate/Senior Research Associate in History, Lancaster University<br>Department of History, Lancaster University<br>Salary: \ufffd\ufffd25,759 to \ufffd\ufffd36,661<br>Closing Date: Thursday 12 June 2014<br>Further details: https://hr-jobs.lancs.ac.uk/Vacancy.aspx?ref=A992<br>Reference: A992<br><br>We wish to appoint a Research Associate with expertise in nineteenth century demography, social history or historical geography for an exciting post in a major research team. You will work closely with Prof Ian Gregory and an inter-disciplinary group of researchers at Lancaster University. The project, Spatial Humanities: Text, GIS, Places (www.lancs.ac.uk/spatialhum<http://www.lancs.ac.uk/spatialhum>), funded by the European Research Council, has developed GIS approaches to manipulating and analysing large volumes of text. We now [...] Hilary Geoghegan 2014-05-23T13:29:25+01:00 2014-05-23T13:29:25+01:00 RGS-IBG HGRG 2014 Undergraduate Dissertation Prize https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=HISTORY-GIS;a3ee2cae.1405 Dear all,<br><br>Apologies for cross-posting. If you have supervised or heard about a first<br>class undergraduate dissertation relating to historical geography (academic<br>year 13/14, UK only) please do consider entering it for the HGRG prize.<br>Last year we had 6 high quality entries and look forward to receiving more<br>this year.<br><br>Details can be found here:<br>http://historicalgeographyresearchgroup.wordpress.com/grants-and-prizes/undergraduate-dissertation-prize/ [...] Rosie Temple 2014-05-21T15:32:53+01:00 2014-05-21T15:32:53+01:00 Daytime Population Movements Workshop - 5th June https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=HISTORY-GIS;15169e52.1405 Daytime Population Movements Workshop<br><br>Date: June 5, 2014<br>Organising Institution: University of Leeds (As part of TALISMAN, an ESRC funded project and NCRM node aimed at enhancing research methods across the UK)<br>Course description:<br>This one day workshop will include contributions from research teams who have a variety of perspectives on short-term movement patterns within cities and regions. These will range from data-intensive methodologies to more theoretical views of process and dynamics.<br>The purpose of the workshop is to add impetus to the discussion of important challenges in developing the study of population mobility from long-term, strategic observations e.g. of [...] Karl Grossner 2014-05-21T00:31:15+01:00 2014-05-21T00:31:15+01:00 Re: 18th century European roads? https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=HISTORY-GIS;46c0eff3.1405 Thank you, Tomasz, Jan, Christos and Jack, your replies have been helpful.<br><br>I'm learning that there are a handful of quite detailed spatial data sets for European countries at a national scale, but that not all have roads. Also that road data is problematic before the 19th century. For those with continent-wide questions, the patchy coverage is problematic. The course will be delivered through presentations [...] Rosie Temple 2014-05-19T16:01:21+01:00 2014-05-19T16:01:21+01:00 Introduction to Geographical Information Systems - Using Quantum GIS June 19-20, 2014 https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=HISTORY-GIS;6540fbdc.1405 **Apologies for any cross-posting**<br><br>Introduction to Geographical Information Systems - Using Quantum GIS June 19-20, 2014<br><br>Organising Institution: The University of Leeds (As part of TALISMAN, an ESRC funded project and NCRM node aimed at enhancing research methods across the UK)<br><br>Times: 10 am - 5pm (June 19) and 10 am - 2pm (June 20) [...] Tomasz Zwi\ufffd\ufffdzek 2014-05-17T22:25:39+02:00 2014-05-17T22:25:39+02:00 Re: 18th cent. roads - POLAND https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=HISTORY-GIS;360fbac6.1405 Full message available at: <a href="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=HISTORY-GIS;360fbac6.1405">Re: 18th cent. roads - POLAND </a> Tomasz Zwi\ufffd\ufffdzek 2014-05-17T21:29:09+01:00 2014-05-17T21:29:09+01:00 Re: 18th century European roads? https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=HISTORY-GIS;f114f83b.1405 Dear Dr. Grossner,<br><br>I am writing as a worker of the "Department of the Historical Atlas of Poland in 16th cent". I have recived group e-mail from prof. Bogumi\ufffd\ufffd Szady. I would like to share with you information about datas we own in the Department, and the whole Polish HGIS-project.<br><br>First please look at our webside (now it is a beta version, full one will be published in 2017): http://hgis.kul.lublin.pl/mapy/pmapper-4.2.0/map_default.phtml?language=en (EN version). The webside is called "The Atlas of Sources and Materials to the History of the Old Poland" (PL: Atlas \ufffd\ufffdr\ufffd\ufffdde\ufffd\ufffd i materia\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdw do dziej\ufffd\ufffdw dawnej Polski). On this [...] Christos N\ufffd\ufffdssli 2014-05-17T09:29:05+02:00 2014-05-17T09:29:05+02:00 Re: 18th century European roads? https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=HISTORY-GIS;3b37c0a3.1405 Le 13.05.2014 16:55, Karl Grossner a \ufffd\ufffdcrit :<br>> Is anyone aware of GIS data for 17-18c European roads? Our goal is first a map covering major cities and roads/rivers between them; ultimately a platform for adding (scholarly crowd)-sourced detail. But if such a thing exists, better to start there.<br>><br>> Barring that, opinions on what the best candidate analog maps for digitizing might be are most welcome.<br>><br>> _______________________<br>> Karl Grossner<br>> Digital Humanities Research Developer<br>> Stanford University Libraries<br>> .<br>><br>The /1781 Rocque Post-Roads of Europe/ may be of some help too (although<br> [...] Karl Grossner 2014-05-17T06:07:13+01:00 2014-05-17T06:07:13+01:00 Re: 18th century European roads? https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=HISTORY-GIS;3b994a9e.1405 Thank you Jack, and Jan,<br><br>This confirms our assessment so far, that there are really no such general digital data sources for roads (and/or routes) in the long Early Modern period. Jan, we have access to the Cassini map here (Rumsey's collection is on it's way into Stanford) and we spoke of this but what a daunting prospect. We're thinking now to just get at major cities and "principle" routes for all of Europe because the Grand Tour is the immediate research topic, also to record journey waypoints then infer routes from terrain. [...] J. B. Owens 2014-05-16T12:02:08-06:00 2014-05-16T12:02:08-06:00 Re: 18th century European roads? https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=HISTORY-GIS;4498285c.1405 Hi Karl,<br><br>This is an exciting project. My former graduate student, Robert Hibberd,<br>and I are about to submit an article on the major routes of the Iberian<br>Peninsula (the "Spain" of the period) in the mid-16th century. We will<br>also bring online the data set Robert prepared from the 1546 guide we<br>use as the basis of the study. The guide described in some detail 139<br>routes, which it did not equate to 139 roads because some of the routes<br>overlapped, as you might expect for a guide that described both<br>commercial and pilgrimage routes. [...] Rosie Temple 2014-05-14T15:25:10+01:00 2014-05-14T15:25:10+01:00 Computer Programming for Social Scientists - TALISMAN Summer School, Leeds https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=HISTORY-GIS;dbf637d0.1405 [cid:image001.jpg@01CF6619.3C1EF0F0]<br><br>[cid:image002.jpg@01CF6619.3C1EF0F0]<br><br>Please use the following link to get further information and to apply:<br><br>http://www.geog.leeds.ac.uk/research/events/computer-programming-for-social-scientists/ Jan Spoor 2014-05-13T11:59:18-04:00 2014-05-13T11:59:18-04:00 Re: 18th century European roads? https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=HISTORY-GIS;58992f26.1405 Through invovlement with a number of amateur kreigsspiel societies, I've<br>come across a number of digital historical map archives that might be of<br>use if you can't find existing GIS data. Most are later (early or late 19th<br>or 20th century), but the one map set that seems like a good candidate<br>would be the Cassini maps of France: 182 sheets covering all of France at<br>1:86,400. Although it was not fully published until 1815, I believe all the<br>surveying was completed between 1740 and 1780 [...] Karl Grossner 2014-05-13T15:55:32+01:00 2014-05-13T15:55:32+01:00 18th century European roads? https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=HISTORY-GIS;df8e5f23.1405 Is anyone aware of GIS data for 17-18c European roads? Our goal is first a map covering major cities and roads/rivers between them; ultimately a platform for adding (scholarly crowd)-sourced detail. But if such a thing exists, better to start there.<br><br>Barring that, opinions on what the best candidate analog maps for digitizing might be are most welcome. Gregory, Ian 2014-05-12T16:40:14+00:00 2014-05-12T16:40:14+00:00 Free summer school in GIS in the Digital Humanities https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=HISTORY-GIS;f46aa41a.1405 GIS for the Digital Humanities: Part of the Lancaster Summer School in Interdisciplinary Digital Methods<br><br>Lancaster University, 15-18th July, 2014<br>http://ucrel.lancs.ac.uk/summerschool/dh-gis.php<br><br>Geographical Information Systems (GIS) are becoming increasingly used by historians, archaeologists, literary scholars, classicists and others, however adoption of the technology has been hampered by a lack of understanding of what GIS is and what it has to offer to these disciplines. It builds on basic knowledge of data manipulation, mapping and analysis, introducing the Spatial Analyst extension.
